docs.lead_paragraph: On an eight-city tour for Weight Watchers, for which she is a spokeswoman, Sarah Ferguson, the Duchess of York, said yesterday that membership to such anti-obesity groups should be covered by Medicare or Medicaid. Great Britain's health care system is considering such a proposal, she told 700 Weight Watcher enthusiasts at a meeting in Amherst, a Buffalo suburb. ''Yes, I can travel around inspiring people,'' said Ms. Ferguson, who has lobbied on Capitol Hill on weight-related health issues. ''But let's get the country to be a bit more supportive and realizing it's a killer.''

docs.lead_paragraph: The Kentucky Education Association, a union representing 45,000 public school teachers, plans to stage a one-day strike on Monday to protest a proposal to nearly triple the cost of health benefits for teachers, school employees and state workers. The union said that if health insurance costs did not remain in line with costs in nearby states, teachers would be urged to strike indefinitely, starting on Oct. 27. Gov. Ernie Fletcher, a Republican, warned that a 1970 court order prohibited the teachers from striking. Last month he proposed a plan that would save the state $150 million by raising insurance deductibles to $800 and tripling the cost of co-payments. Albert Salvato (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: The union representing 28,000 janitors and other building-service workers at 1,000 New York City office towers will vote on Thursday whether to authorize a strike beginning Oct. 1. The union, Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, is engaged in negotiations with building owners and managers over how to close a $150 million annual deficit in the union's health fund. Tomorrow, more than 10,000 of Local 32BJ's building-service workers on Long Island and in New Jersey, Connecticut and Westchester County will vote on whether to authorize strikes in separate but related contract negotiations. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: A LITTLE-NOTICED provision in the Medicare prescription drug law passed by Congress late last year is starting to shake up the group insurance market for small businesses. The provision created health savings accounts that allow people to set aside pretax income to pay medical bills. When linked to high-deductible insurance policies, the accounts, known as H.S.A.'s, can drastically lower an employer's costs of providing employee health benefits. This may allow more small businesses to offer such benefits -- or provide savings for those that already do.

docs.lead_paragraph: PRESIDENT BUSH says he loves small business, and small-business owners are overwhelmingly on his side in the election. But entrepreneurs are not yet giving Mr. Bush the one thing he needs the most: a surge in jobs. For nearly 20 years now, political leaders of all stripes have taken it as gospel truth that small companies are responsible for about two-thirds of all new jobs created in the United States. (Senator John Kerry, who is as enthusiastic a small-business cheerleader as his opponent, outdoes him on this score, crediting the sector with 75 percent of all new jobs.)

headline.main: Where Do The Jobs Come From?

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: When I started my practice in osteopathy 60 years ago, every health care dollar went to the cost of care. Today, the exorbitant salaries of managed care chief executives, their employees' salaries, the cost of paying claims, stockholder dividends and other office expenses greatly reduce the amount of money available for medical care. The financial statements of many of these managed care plans show significant profits. Does this not explain, in part, the soaring cost of medical premiums?

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Those Soaring Medicare Premiums'' (editorial, Sept. 17) correctly judges both the Bush and Kerry approaches to cost control as unlikely to work, but says nothing about alternatives that might be effective. Health care cost inflation has many causes, the most important of which are the increasing use of expensive new technology (including drugs) and the growing industrialization of health care, with entrepreneurial incentives and high overhead.
